awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Intra-Organizational Boundary Spanning: Strategic Implications for the Design, Implementation, and Use of Enterprise Social Media
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will explore the potential of enterprise social media (ESM) for enhancing inter-group cross-boundary communications and performance of collaborative organizational groups. Enhancing the performance of organizational groups is critical to industrial success and the economic competitiveness of organizations in the United States. The study will provide implications for the strategic design and organizational implementation of ESM tools to enhance their impact on collaboration and innovation and offer specific guidelines for the design of ESM platforms aimed at evoking and enhancing collaboration and boundary spanning in other cyber-human systems. The project will also produce relevant materials for the education and training of students.

This project is motivated by two recent scientific developments. On the one hand, there is growing recognition of the need to study social media in groups and to explore its potential for supporting a range of group and organizational outcomes. On the other hand, the recent literature on boundary-spanning has proposed the need for shifting the focus to virtual contexts and in particular assessing how the use of virtual tools (e.g. ESM) affects boundary-spanning success. This study responds to both developments with a longitudinal, multi-level, and mixed-method empirical study of the relations between ESM use and intra-organizational boundary spanning. The research will address four related research questions: 1) the types of boundary-spanning activities that occur using ESM; 2) the effect of these activities on group performance; 3) the impact of a group's degree of virtuality; and 4) the effect of the affordances and privacy settings embedded in the ESM platform on boundary spanning and group effectiveness. The proposed approach entails a dynamic multimodal network analysis complemented with mixed-method data for providing a processual understanding of the effect of ESM on intra-organizational boundary spanning and group performance. The study will provide several contributions to the ESM and boundary spanning literature. First, it will contribute to the development of a conceptual and operational apparatus for understanding how ESM supports boundary spanning. Second, the project will contribute an understanding of ESM use at the inter-group and intra-organizational level, thereby extending the current individual-level focus that has dominated much of the social media literature. Third, the project will contribute an understanding of the (a) effectiveness of virtual tools in supporting boundary-spanning activities, (b) the optimal configurations of network relations for supporting these activities, and (c) the effect of other node variables and tie characteristics on the relation between ESM use, boundary spanning, and the performance of collaborative groups.

por.por_cntn:
Social media have become increasingly important, not only for individual users, but also for organizations. Although the focus until recently has been on how organizations use social media for marketing purposes (i.e., to interact with customers), organizations are increasingly using social media internally in the hopes of breaking down silos in the organization and increasing the extent of knowledge sharing and collaboration across internal organizational boundaries, a process referred to as boundary spanning. Indeed, 80% of companies are now using some form of enterprise social media (ESM) and worldwide spending has been estimated at $100 billion. However, despite this interest and investment, many companies have struggled to establish fully active systems and increase actual collaboration.

In order to understand if and how ESM are used for boundary-spanning, we conducted a series of interviews, surveys, and analyses of behavioral data to examine not only the different ways teams of ESM users engage in cross-boundary knowledge sharing and collaboration, but also to understand how the nature of the team—e.g., how diverse or how distributed the team is—and the nature of the ESM platform—e.g., different team privacy settings—impact the likelihood of teams using ESM for collaboration. Surveys and interviews helped us understand the different types of users that exist in ESM as well as what motivates users to use ESM for work purposes—such as knowledge-sharing—or mostly for social purposes—such as sharing pictures and planning outings. Furthermore, we also used social network analysis to understand the reciprocal process of boundary spanning, something that had not been studied before, as previous research has only focused on the goals of the boundary-spanner but not on the responses of others who might provide the requested information or resource. Additionally, we employed longitudinal methods to visualize if successful versus unsuccessful project teams display different patterns of boundary-spanning behaviors and developed a dashboard to visualize these patterns. This can help team managers detect early on if a team is likely to fail, and give them opportunities to provide support for the right types of activities that are likely to increase project success.

Underpinning the project has been a seminal theory on boundary-spanning that identifies three distinct boundary-spanning activities, namely representation, coordination, and information search. Our project has focused on developing new ways to measure these three types of activities using behavioral data generated during system use. Existing management research has shown that teams that engage in boundary spanning show higher levels of project success, higher client satisfaction, and greater innovativeness. With this project, we have researched how teams use ESM to practice these three types of boundary spanning, how it affects team success, and how it is mediated by characteristics of the team and the platform.

This project has resulted in a variety of relevant insights. First, we found that about 20% of all interactions on ESM are social and the majority (80%) of interactions are work-related. Furthermore, from the work-related activities, about two-thirds involve some form of boundary spanning. Second, we have discovered important links between the nature of the team and the types of boundary-spanning activities they are most successful accomplishing. Specifically, we found that groups with more differentiation in their internal management hierarchy are more successful at representation—lobbying for resources and recognition for the team—and teams that are more geographically distributed are more successful at coordinating and obtaining knowledge from outside the group. Third, we found that the privacy settings of teams significantly affect the nature of activities teams are likely to perform; more specifically, visible teams are better at representation and secret teams are better at coordination and information sharing. Finally, we found that successful teams display a different pattern of boundary spanning over time than unsuccessful ones; an insight that can be used by managers to improve team performance.

With this funding, we have published 4 peer-reviewed research papers in high-impact journals and 10 in peer-reviewed conference proceedings as well as given multiple invited keynotes at high-profile industry events. We involved a total of 19 undergraduate, 5 Master and 3 PhD students on this work. We built and implemented a dashboard that is used by the ESM team at our partner organization. We developed a conceptual framework for theorizing how the use of ESM impacts boundary spanning and introduced new theoretical concepts and operational measures into the field of management and information systems studies.

We are grateful for the support of the NSF through this award. This support has helped us make a significant impact on ESM research as well as on practitioners in this space.
